newsitem.title: SINGAPORE: Asia Fuel Oil - Firm in line with crude gains.
newsitem.headline: Asia Fuel Oil - Firm in line with crude gains.

text.p: The Singapore high sulphur fuel oil market maintaind its firm tone on Thursday, tracking gains in the crude market for the second day, traders said.
September Brent crude closed up 38 cents per barrel to $18.97 on the International Petroleum Exchange on Wednesday and gained another three cents on SIMEX.
Singapore's declining fuel oil stocks also slightly boosted prices, traders said.
Singapore's weekly fuel oil residues fell by 219,000 barrels to 10.855 million in the week ending July 30, Singapore's Trade Development Board (TDB) data showed on Thursday.
The weekly stocks have been falling in the past three weeks.
The 180-cst grade was offered at $102.25 per tonne, compared with the $101.75 traded level on Wednesday, for late August lifting but no deals were heard on late Thursday.
Fuel oil swaps also firmed, with both August and September quoted at $101.25/$102.00, up from Wednesday's $100.75/$101.75.
"It seems the market will continue to follow the strong crude market for a while," said one trader.
However, the trader noted a lack of fresh buying demand and saw limited gains.
Other traders also noted the low American Pertroleum Institute stocks data.
Taiwan's state-owned Chinese Petroleum Corp (CPC) issued a tender on Thursday to buy two low-sulphur fuel oil cargoes for delivery in September.
The tender seeks to buy one 0.5-percent and one 1.0 percent low-pour cargoes for delivery in the second half of September, a company source said.
The tender closes on August 6 and is valid for two days.
The low sulphur waxy residue (LSWR) market was under pressure amid higher supplies from Indonesia in August than in July, traders said.
Indonesia's state oil company Pertamina allocated a total of 2.7 million barrels of LSWR for August lifting and traders expected further allocation in late August.
(Prices in dollars per tonne, unless stated)
MTH FOB SIN BUY/SELL PREV BUY/SELL
*Dollars per barrel
-- Singapore newsroom (+65-870 3571)
